boat.name: Witch
boat.full_description:
Built by A M Dickie of Tarbert for William James Yorke Scarlett, the Laird of Gigha, she was named 'Belem' after the French three masted barque which was famous for its speed. Used principally as a ferry to and from the mainland, she was originally flush-decked with the skylight set in the deck. Her design is quite advanced for the time with her three-quarter length keel and cutaway stem. In 1918 she had the coachroof added which adds significantly to the headroom.

In 2013, she took part in the OGA Round Britain Challenge, visit Sailing by and the Witch website for more details.
boat.short_description: Witch, a gaff-rigged cutter, is a yacht originally built as a ferry in 1898 for the Laird of Gigha on the western isles of Scotland.

for_sales.sales_text: Witch was built by Dickies of Tarbert as the private ferry yacht for the Laird of Gigha in 1898. Her full history is known and she has been well cared for over the years. Her structure is mostly original and she has recently had her below the waterline caulking raked and replaced with traditional cotton and red lead stopping. Below decks she was re-fitted in 1918 and then again in 1963. This latter was not comfortable and was replaced with a standard layout with galley and nav station in 2007.
